etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French roialte, from roial (see royal). The sense ‘royal right (especially over minerals’) (late 15th century) developed into the sense ‘payment made by a mineral producer to the site owner’ (mid 19th century), which was then transferred to payments for the use of patents and published materials

definitions: people of royal blood or status

examples.text: diplomats, heads of state, and royalty shared tables at the banquet

shortDefinitions: people of royal blood or status

definitions: a member of a royal family

examples.text: she swept by as if she were royalty

definitions: the status or power of a king or queen

examples.text: the brilliance of her clothes, her jewels, all revealed her royalty

shortDefinitions: status or power of king or queen

definitions: the most successful, famous, or highly regarded members of a particular group

examples.text: it's not often you meet real Hollywood royalty, let alone chat to Angelina Jolie and Dustin Hoffman in one day

shortDefinitions: most successful or famous members of particular group

definitions: a sum of money paid to a patentee for the use of a patent or to an author or composer for each copy of a book sold or for each public performance of a work

examples.text: the royalties paid to writers for recorded music

shortDefinitions: sum paid to patentee for use of patent or to author or composer for each copy of book

definitions: a royal right (now especially over minerals) granted by the sovereign to an individual or corporation.
a payment made by a producer of minerals, oil, or natural gas to the owner of the site or of the mineral rights over it.
shortDefinitions: payment made by producer of minerals, oil
